P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 10,000Mt?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile
Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 10,000Mt?

not_P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 not exceed 10,000Mt?
not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or

Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve negatively is one in which stockpiles include a total of 10,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

para_P.title: By the conclusion of 2029, will the cumulative yield from the nuclear arsenals of all nations surpass 10,000Mt?
para_P.body:
Criteria for Resolution
The resolution will rely on the latest estimates released in 2029 by credible organizations such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). In the absence of explicit estimates from reputable sources regarding the total yield from all countries' nuclear arsenals in 2029, the resolution will be determined by Metaculus administrators, who will:
consult with an author of pertinent studies (for instance, Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
provide an estimate based on information from credible sources regarding aspects such as the quantity of various types of weapons and their respective yields, or the counts and average yields of each country's nuclear stockpile.
Important Note
An instance where this inquiry would yield a positive resolution is if the stockpiles contain more than 20,000 warheads with an average yield of 500kt.

Q.title: Will armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, either of the following occur:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolves as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 10,000Mt, and (b) armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
1. The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 will exceed 10,000Mt based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
   - ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
   - make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile.
   Fine Print: One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.
2. Armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China will lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050 if, at any time between January 1, 2021, to January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs:
   - There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
   - There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
   These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period. This question will resolve as No otherwise.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 10,000Mt? (b) Will armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution for the first question will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile.
Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

Resolution for the second question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, either of the following occur:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050 and (b) the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 not exceed 10,000Mt?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met:
1. At any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, either of the following occur regarding armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China:
   - There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
   - There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
   These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
2. The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 does not exceed 10,000Mt, based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will ask an author of relevant publications for an estimate, and/or make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile. 
This question will resolve as No otherwise.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 10,000Mt? (b) Will armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For (a), the resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile.
Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

For (b), this question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, either of the following occur:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceeds 10,000Mt, will armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceeds 10,000Mt. Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile. 

Then is it true that armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China will lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050? This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, either of the following occur: There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths, or there are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths. These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period. This question will resolve as No otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceeds 10,000Mt, and (2) armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met:
1. The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceeds 10,000Mt. Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
   - ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
   - make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile.
   Fine Print: One example of a scenario where this condition would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.
2. Armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050. This condition will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, either of the following occur:
   - There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
   - There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
   These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period. This condition will resolve as No otherwise.

cons_P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 8,000Mt?

Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). Fine Print

metadata.background_info:
For further context and motivation for this and other questions in this tournament on nuclear proliferation, force sizes, or yields, and a list of such questions, see here.
The total yield across all arsenals depends on both the number of weapons in states' stockpiles and the yield of each of those weapons. This tournament has or will soon have other questions on the number of nuclear weapons that'll be in states' stockpiles and the largest yield weapon that'll be possessed.
Stockpiles include deployed, reserve/nondeployed, and retired (but still intact) warheads, and both strategic and nonstrategic weapons. If states that aren't currently nuclear-armed are nuclear-armed when the latest estimated published in 2029 are made, their stockpiles can count towards positive resolution.

not_P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 not exceed 8,000Mt?

Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile
Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve negatively is one in which stockpiles include a total of 8,000 warheads or fewer and their mean yield is less than or equal to 500kt.

para_P.title: By the conclusion of 2029, will the cumulative output of nuclear arsenals from all nations surpass 8,000Mt?
para_P.body:
Criteria for Resolution
The determination will rely on the latest figures released in 2029 from credible organizations such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). In the absence of clear estimates from reputable sources regarding the total output of all countries' nuclear arsenals in 2029, the resolution will be decided by Metaculus administrators, who will:
consult with an author of pertinent studies (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
formulate an estimate based on information from credible sources about factors like the quantity of different types of weapons and their respective yields, or the total numbers and average yields of each nation's nuclear stockpile.
Additional Notes
An example of a situation that would lead to a positive resolution of this question is if the stockpiles contain over 20,000 warheads with an average yield of 500kt.

Q.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 8,000Mt and (b) there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceeds 8,000Mt, based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate this total yield, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will ask an author of relevant publications for an estimate and/or make an estimate based on reputable sources' data about the number of weapons and their yields. (2) There has been at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100, determined by a period of at least 5 consecutive years where the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880, using data primarily from NASA.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 8,000Mt? (b) Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
1. For the first question, resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
   - ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
   - make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile.
   Fine Print: One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

2. For the second question, this will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalized relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100, and (b) the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 not exceed 8,000Mt?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880, with critical value being 1.8 ˚C based on NASA's dataset. (2) Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS), indicating that the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles does not exceed 8,000Mt. If no reputable sources provide estimates, resolution will be determined by Metaculus admins based on relevant estimations.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 8,000Mt? (b) Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For (a), resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or

Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

For (b), this question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalized relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceeds 8,000Mt, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria: 
1. The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 must exceed 8,000Mt. 
 - Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
   - ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
   - make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile.
2. By January 1, 2100, there must have been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. 
 - Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. The critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to ensure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceeds 8,000Mt (2) There will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) The total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceeds 8,000Mt, based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS), or as determined by Metaculus admins if no reputable sources provide an estimate. (2) There has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years by January 1, 2100, in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880, with data for resolution coming from NASA or another reputable source if necessary.

P.title: Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reach majority in the Electoral college before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030.

P.title: Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reach majority in the Electoral college before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030.

not_P.title: Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact not reach majority in the Electoral college before 2030?
not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if fewer than five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030.

para_P.title: Will a majority of the Electoral College support the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact prior to 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be considered true if no fewer than five trustworthy media outlets confirm that states totaling at least 50% of Electoral College votes have endorsed the NPVIC before the year 2030.

Q.title: Before 2025, will at least two public health agencies claim that China deliberately misreported COVID-19 infections?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The COVID-19 outbreak in China has been rife with allegations of misrepresentation by Chinese government officials. These began at the local level, where officials in Hubei province potentially under-reported the magnitude of the outbreak in early January to Chinese central government authorities. A public health worker famously released a video around January 26 claiming that at that time, at least 90,000 cases had occurred--at the time the Chinese government was reporting fewer than 2000 infections. Since then, the insufficiently-inclusive strategy of counting only persons with laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 depressed the counts of probable cases. And the patterns of growth in the official counts follow an unexpected distribution, implying the counts may be generated by a model which doesn't accurately represent the dynamics of the disease's spread through the population.
This latter allegation is perhaps the most important and severe, as it means that estimations of epidemiological characteristics based on Chinese data may lead to public health interventions which do not reflect the reality of the viral spread. For example, if the R_0 (the average number of people an infected person will pass the virus along to) is underestimated, it may lead to insufficiently aggressive strategies for reducing the propagation of the virus across the globe. However, overestimating it could lead to overly-aggressive quarantining strategies, hobbling international commerce. Getting a proper assessment of the epidemiological dynamics is critical to devising the appropriate public health response.
Will at least two public health agencies publicly accuse the Chinese government of deliberately misrepresenting the number of COVID-19 infections before 2025?
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, at least two of the public health agencies listed below claim that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately lied about, fabricated, or misrepresented case or death numbers. If an agency claims that the numbers were flawed, but does not go as far as to suggest deliberate lying or misrepresentation, this will not count. For the purpose of this question, we consider only statements by the following public health agencies:
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (including the Epidemic Intelligence Service)
The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (including the Health Threat Unit)
World Health Organization
The Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
The Centre for Health Protection
Robert Koch Institute
The National Institute of Infectious Diseases
Public Health England
The National Centre for Infectious Diseases
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Korea
The Public Health Agency of Canada
In case multiple subdivisions of any of the above agencies make assessments that China more likely than not lied about case or death numbers, these will only count as single accusation made by a single agency.
The relevant assessments will count if they are judged by Metaculus to broadly state that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately did lie about, fabricate, or misrepresent case or death counts.
This question has a short-fuse sister.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact will reach majority in the Electoral College before 2030, and (2) before 2025, at least two public health agencies will claim that China deliberately misreported COVID-19 infections?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) At least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact (NPVIC) before 2030, and (2) before January 1, 2025, at least two of the specified public health agencies claim that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately lied about, fabricated, or misrepresented case or death numbers.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reach majority in the Electoral College before 2030? (b) Before 2025, at least two public health agencies claim that China deliberately misreported COVID-19 infections?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if either of the following occurs: (1) At least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030. (2) Before January 1, 2025, at least two of the listed public health agencies claim that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately lied about, fabricated, or misrepresented case or death numbers.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) At least two public health agencies publicly accuse the Chinese government of deliberately misrepresenting COVID-19 infections before 2025, and (2) the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact will not reach majority in the Electoral College before 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Before January 1, 2025, at least two of the specified public health agencies claim that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately misrepresented the number of COVID-19 infections; and (2) fewer than five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact before 2030.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reaches majority in the Electoral College before 2030? (b) Before 2025, at least two public health agencies claim that China deliberately misreported COVID-19 infections?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if at least one of the following occurs: (1) At least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact before 2030. (2) Before January 1, 2025, at least two of the specified public health agencies claim that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately lied about, fabricated, or misrepresented COVID-19 case or death numbers.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reaches majority in the Electoral College before 2030, will at least two public health agencies claim that China deliberately misreported COVID-19 infections before 2025?
Q_given_P.body: Suppose the following is true: The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reaches majority in the Electoral College before 2030, meaning that at least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030. Then, will at least two public health agencies publicly accuse the Chinese government of deliberately misrepresenting the number of COVID-19 infections before 2025? This resolves as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, at least two of the specified public health agencies claim that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately lied about, fabricated, or misrepresented case or death numbers.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact will reach majority in the Electoral College before 2030 (2) Before 2025, at least two public health agencies will claim that China deliberately misreported COVID-19 infections?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) At least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least half of Electoral College votes have signed the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact (NPVIC) before 2030. (2) Before January 1, 2025, at least two of the specified public health agencies publicly accuse the Chinese government of deliberately lying about, fabricating, or misrepresenting COVID-19 case or death numbers.

cons_P.title: Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reach 40% of the Electoral college before 2030?
cons_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030.

metadata.background_info: The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact is a an agreement among states to award all of their electoral votes to the candidate with the highest popular vote, conditional on enough states agreeing that the total electoral vote count would secure a majority in the electoral college. In effect, the agreement means that if enough states sign on, the popular vote will determine the outcome of presidential elections. So far states representing 196 electoral votes have signed on, which is 73% of the way to the 270 required to obtain a majority in the Electoral College.

P.title: Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reach 40% of the Electoral college before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030.

metadata.background_info: The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact is a an agreement among states to award all of their electoral votes to the candidate with the highest popular vote, conditional on enough states agreeing that the total electoral vote count would secure a majority in the electoral college. In effect, the agreement means that if enough states sign on, the popular vote will determine the outcome of presidential elections. So far states representing 196 electoral votes have signed on, which is 73% of the way to the 270 required to obtain a majority in the Electoral College.

not_P.title: Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact not reach 40% of the Electoral college before 2030?
not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if there are no reliable media sources reporting that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030.

para_P.title: Will 40% of the Electoral College endorse the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact prior to 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be considered true if a minimum of five credible media outlets confirm that states accounting for at least 40% of Electoral College votes have ratified the NPVIC before the year 2030.

Q.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reaches 40% of the Electoral College before 2030, and (2) there is at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) At least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact (NPVIC) before 2030, and (2) by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. 
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalized relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reach 40% of the Electoral College before 2030? (b) Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030 OR if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100, and (b) the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact will not reach 40% of the Electoral College before 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880, which is equivalent to 1.8 ˚C using the NASA dataset. (2) There are no reliable media sources reporting that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact before 2030.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reach 40% of the Electoral College before 2030? (b) Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030 (part a), OR if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880 (part b). Data for the global warming resolution shall come from NASA, if possible, and the critical value to look for with the specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C.

Q_given_P.title: Given the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reaches 40% of the Electoral College before 2030, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Suppose the following is true: The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact (NPVIC) reaches at least 40% of the Electoral College before 2030, as reported by at least five reliable media sources. Then, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by January 1, 2100? This question resolves positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. The data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible, with the critical value to look for being 1.8 ˚C.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reaches 40% of the Electoral College before 2030, and (2) there is at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if both of the following conditions are met: (1) At least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact (NPVIC) before 2030. (2) By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880, with data for resolution coming from NASA, if possible.

P.title: Will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

P.title: Will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

not_P.title: Will 50% or fewer of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that 50% or fewer of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

para_P.title: By the year 2050, will over half of adults in the United States possess a personal augmented reality device?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if, at any point before January 1, 2050, a credible survey indicates that more than 50% of adults in the US own any kind of personal augmented reality device. 
For the purpose of this inquiry, a personal augmented reality device is characterized as portable and designed for personal use in various locations, with its main function centered around augmented reality capabilities. "Augmented reality capabilities" refer to the generation of digital information and visuals that are superimposed on the user's perception of their actual surroundings, updating in real time as the user engages with both the digital and physical environments. A handheld smartphone that is occasionally utilized for augmented reality purposes would not be considered valid (as AR is not its primary function).
If there is any indication that a survey includes a significant number of devices that do not meet the criteria for resolution, the administrators will exercise their best judgment or opt for an alternative survey or method if available, or determine the question to be ambiguous at their discretion.

Q.title: Will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Nick Bostrom, philosopher and Founding Director of the Future of Humanity Institute at the University of Oxford, argues that only two events since the dawn of humanity have fundamentally changed the human condition: the Agricultural Revolution that took place approximately 10,000 years ago, and the Industrial Revolution which took place from roughly 1760-1840. Bostrom states the following:
"So what kind of thing would count as a fundamental change in the human condition?
"You could argue that if we look back over history, there has really only been two events that have fundamentally changed the human condition, the first being the Agricultural Revolution some 10,000 or 12,000 years ago in Mesopotamia, where we transitioned from being hunter-gatherers, small bands roaming around, to settling into cities, growing, domesticating crops and animals. With that you get social stratification, if there is a lot of grain, you could have a king or pharaoh who extracts the surplus, you can have standing armies, you can have war, you can have higher population densities, specialisation of labour, and from that point on, innovation grows much faster and population grows faster as well as a result.
"The second fundamental change in the human condition, Industrial Revolution, where for the first time, you have the rate of economic and technological growth outstripping population growth, and so only when this happens can you have an increase in average income. Before that, there was technological growth and economic growth, but the economy grew 10%, the population grew 10%, everybody's still in a Malthusian condition."
Bostrom further argues that there are relatively few potential technologies that could have the same kind of impact, and that perhaps foremost among them is machine intelligence.
The kind of discontinuity in the human condition seen as a result of the agricultural and industrial revolutions is substantial; human civilisation became markedly more complex, acquired fundamentally new abilities, and the human experience became radically different after each of these events.
The question we ask here is: Before January 1 2100, will the human condition change fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions?
"The human condition," for the purposes of this question, is the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality humanity has achieved at the civilisational level.
The discontinuity can be in either direction - though it seems improbable that Metaculus would continue to exist if humanity were to revert to a pre-industrial state.
Events that may occur this century, but which do not appear to represent a discontinuity of approximately the same degree as the agricultural and industrial revolutions, include (among other things) the establishment of bases or settlements on other bodies in the solar system, the achievement of modest to moderate life extension (e.g. an additional 10 to 30 years of life) or a significant but not radical increase in economic productivity.
Resolution
If at any time after the date of 2025-01-01 both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, the question resolves positively or negatively, respectively. With 20% probability, the question resolves according to a committee of 5 Metaculus admins, who will vote yes or no (not ambiguous), and will unmake their respective predictions so that they do not gain or lose points on the question.
Note that the admins will be voting on whether the qualifying event has already happened, not whether they believe it will happen; for example, if the probability goes to 99% because a super-powerful AI seems immininent within 10 years, but it has not actually happened yet, the committee should unanimously vote no.
If the question has not resolved by January 1 2100, it resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050 and (b) the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following are true: (1) anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device, defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions; and (2) before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, which is determined by the community and Metaculus predictions reaching >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, and a committee of 5 Metaculus admins voting on whether the qualifying event has already happened.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) More than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050 (b) The human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following is true: (1) Anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device, defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify. (2) Before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, as defined by Nick Bostrom, in terms of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The human condition will change fundamentally before 2100, and (2) 50% or fewer of US adults will own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
1. The human condition will change fundamentally before January 1, 2100, to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions. This will be assessed by whether, after the date of 2025-01-01, both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, or by a committee of 5 Metaculus admins voting on the qualifying event that has already happened.

2. 50% or fewer of US adults will own any type of personal augmented reality device before January 1, 2050, as determined by a credible survey of adults in the US. A personal augmented reality device is defined as portable and intended for augmented reality functions, which produce digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) More than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050? (b) The human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occurs: (a) Anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device, defined as a portable device intended for augmented reality functions. (b) Before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, as determined by the criteria set forth by Nick Bostrom and the Metaculus admins. If the question has not resolved by January 1, 2100, it resolves ambiguously.

Q_given_P.title: Given that more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050, will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2100, it is determined that the human condition has changed fundamentally, as defined by Nick Bostrom, philosopher and Founding Director of the Future of Humanity Institute at the University of Oxford. Bostrom argues that only two events since the dawn of humanity have fundamentally changed the human condition: the Agricultural Revolution that took place approximately 10,000 years ago, and the Industrial Revolution which took place from roughly 1760-1840. He states that a fundamental change in the human condition would be a discontinuity at least roughly the same extent as these two revolutions, affecting social complexity, economic productivity, and humanity's ability to manipulate physical reality.

For the purposes of this question, the human condition is defined as the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality humanity has achieved at the civilisational level. The question will resolve positively if at any time after January 1, 2025, both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, and negatively with 20% probability based on a committee of 5 Metaculus admins who will vote yes or no (not ambiguous).
If the question has not resolved by January 1, 2100, it resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) More than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050, and (2) The human condition changes fundamentally before 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device, which is defined as one that is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, primarily used for augmented reality functions; (2) Before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, including a significant change in social complexity, economic productivity, and humanity's ability to manipulate physical reality.

cons_P.title: Will more than 30% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
cons_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 30% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

metadata.background_info:
The Merriam-Webster Dictionary defines augmented reality (AR) as
an enhanced version of reality created by the use of technology to overlay digital information on an image of something being viewed through a device (such as a smartphone camera)
Some expect AR devices to be much more prevalent in the future. Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about augmented reality in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
By 2050 pretty much everyone will be wearing smart glasses for augmented reality, and eventually these glasses will replace a lot of phones (no one will carry a wallet in 2050).
According to a PEW survey, 85% of US adults said they owned a smartphone in 2021.

P.title: Will more than 30% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria

For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion.

para_P.title: By the year 2050, will over 30% of adults in the United States possess a personal augmented reality device?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will conclude as Yes if, at any point before January 1, 2050, a reliable survey indicates that more than 30% of adults in the US have any kind of personal augmented reality device. 
For the purpose of this question, a personal augmented reality device is characterized as one that is portable and designed to be used by an individual while moving from one location to another, with its main function being augmented reality capabilities. "Augmented reality capabilities" refer to the creation of digital information and images that are superimposed on the user's perception of their actual surroundings, updating in real-time as the user navigates and interacts with both the digital and physical worlds. A handheld smartphone that is sometimes utilized for augmented reality purposes would not be considered (as AR is not its primary function). 
If there is reason to suspect that a survey includes a substantial number of devices that do not meet the criteria for resolving this question, the administrators will exercise their best judgment or employ an alternative survey or method if available, or determine the question to be ambiguous at their discretion.

Q.title: Will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Nick Bostrom, philosopher and Founding Director of the Future of Humanity Institute at the University of Oxford, argues that only two events since the dawn of humanity have fundamentally changed the human condition: the Agricultural Revolution that took place approximately 10,000 years ago, and the Industrial Revolution which took place from roughly 1760-1840. Bostrom states the following:
"So what kind of thing would count as a fundamental change in the human condition?
"You could argue that if we look back over history, there has really only been two events that have fundamentally changed the human condition, the first being the Agricultural Revolution some 10,000 or 12,000 years ago in Mesopotamia, where we transitioned from being hunter-gatherers, small bands roaming around, to settling into cities, growing, domesticating crops and animals. With that you get social stratification, if there is a lot of grain, you could have a king or pharaoh who extracts the surplus, you can have standing armies, you can have war, you can have higher population densities, specialisation of labour, and from that point on, innovation grows much faster and population grows faster as well as a result.
"The second fundamental change in the human condition, Industrial Revolution, where for the first time, you have the rate of economic and technological growth outstripping population growth, and so only when this happens can you have an increase in average income. Before that, there was technological growth and economic growth, but the economy grew 10%, the population grew 10%, everybody's still in a Malthusian condition."
Bostrom further argues that there are relatively few potential technologies that could have the same kind of impact, and that perhaps foremost among them is machine intelligence.
The kind of discontinuity in the human condition seen as a result of the agricultural and industrial revolutions is substantial; human civilisation became markedly more complex, acquired fundamentally new abilities, and the human experience became radically different after each of these events.
The question we ask here is: Before January 1 2100, will the human condition change fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions?
"The human condition," for the purposes of this question, is the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality humanity has achieved at the civilisational level.
The discontinuity can be in either direction - though it seems improbable that Metaculus would continue to exist if humanity were to revert to a pre-industrial state.
Events that may occur this century, but which do not appear to represent a discontinuity of approximately the same degree as the agricultural and industrial revolutions, include (among other things) the establishment of bases or settlements on other bodies in the solar system, the achievement of modest to moderate life extension (e.g. an additional 10 to 30 years of life) or a significant but not radical increase in economic productivity.
Resolution
If at any time after the date of 2025-01-01 both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, the question resolves positively or negatively, respectively. With 20% probability, the question resolves according to a committee of 5 Metaculus admins, who will vote yes or no (not ambiguous), and will unmake their respective predictions so that they do not gain or lose points on the question.
Note that the admins will be voting on whether the qualifying event has already happened, not whether they believe it will happen; for example, if the probability goes to 99% because a super-powerful AI seems immininent within 10 years, but it has not actually happened yet, the committee should unanimously vote no.
If the question has not resolved by January 1 2100, it resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) more than 30% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050, and (b) the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 30% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device, defined as portable devices intended for augmented reality functions, and (2) Before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally, as defined by the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality, to at least the same extent as seen after the agricultural and industrial revolutions. The resolution of the first condition will be based on survey data, while the second condition will be determined by community and Metaculus predictions, with a committee of admins voting if necessary.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) More than 30% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050? (b) The human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occurs: (1) Anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 30% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device, defined as portable devices intended for augmented reality functions, or (2) Before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, as defined by the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality humanity has achieved at the civilisational level. The discontinuity can be in either direction.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) the human condition change fundamentally before 2100 and (b) 30% or fewer of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
1. The human condition will change fundamentally before January 1, 2100 if at any time after the date of 2025-01-01 both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, the question resolves positively or negatively, respectively. With 20% probability, the question resolves according to a committee of 5 Metaculus admins, who will vote yes or no (not ambiguous), and will unmake their respective predictions so that they do not gain or lose points on the question. If the question has not resolved by January 1, 2100, it resolves ambiguously.
2. The ownership of personal augmented reality devices will be 30% or fewer of US adults by January 1, 2050 if at any time before this date, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that 30% or fewer of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device, defined as portable devices intended for augmented reality functions, which produce digital information and images overlaid on the user's view of their real environment.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) More than 30% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050? (b) The human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occurs: 
1. Anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 30% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
2. Before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, as defined by the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality humanity has achieved at the civilisational level.

Q_given_P.title: Given that more than 30% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050, will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Suppose the following is true: More than 30% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050, as determined by a credible survey conducted before January 1, 2050. This personal augmented reality device is defined as portable, intended to accompany a person, and primarily used for augmented reality functions, which produce real-time digital overlays on the user's view of their environment. Given this condition, will the human condition change fundamentally before January 1, 2100, to at least the same extent as after the Agricultural and Industrial Revolutions? The human condition is defined as the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality at the civilizational level. A fundamental change would be events that significantly alter this condition, as per the arguments of philosopher Nick Bostrom. The resolution criteria for this question state that if at any time after January 1, 2025, community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2% with 80% probability, the question resolves positively or negatively, respectively. If unresolved by January 1, 2100, it resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) More than 30% of US adults will own a personal augmented reality device by 2050, and (b) the human condition will change fundamentally before 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 30% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device, defined as portable devices intended for augmented reality functions; and (2) before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, as defined by the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality at the civilizational level. The resolution of the human condition change will be determined by the Metaculus community and admins as specified in the original question.
